Thank you Bob for coming up with a clever and catchy answer to =
the seemingly perennial 
"[how do/should] I test private methods" question.=


I really like the "Testing trumps encapsulation" phrasing because it impl=
ies relative and not 
absolute value judgements.  It meets the spirit of Te=
stivus (http://www.artima.com/
weblogs/viewpost.jsp?thread=3D194506).

Sure=
, ideally the design and implementation is such that you don't have to brea=
k 
encapsulation, but often circumstances are less than ideal.

The assert =
on privates vs. don't assert on privates issue is something that we have be=
en 
debating amongst ourselves at Agitar for years.  The current version of=
 JUnit Factory 
creates asserts for private fields.  I still cringe a littl=
e bit when I see them.  But if we 
remove them, users complain.

A possible=
 solution, suggested by someone else at work, is to partition the generated=
 tests 
into black-box tests and white-box tests src directories.

The blac=
k-box tests can only assert (and use) public stuff - they can't violate 
en=
capsulation.  

The white-box tests can peek and poke wherever they want.

=
I haven't given this idea enought thought to reach a conclusion, but I foun=
d it intriguing 
enough to share it and solicit feedback.
